newsitem.title: USA: South Carolina Gov. urges coastal evacuation.
newsitem.headline: South Carolina Gov. urges coastal evacuation.

text.p: South Carolina Gov. David Beasley on Wednesday urged voluntary relocation of all residents and tourists on barrier islands and beach front property along the coast in anticipation of Hurricane Fran.

Calling Fran a "relentless adversary," Beasley also urged those living in low-lying areas on or near the coast from Little River south to voluntarily evacuate. Hurricane Fran was due to approach coastal South Carolina by mid-morning on Thursday, he said, after consulting with state emergency preparedness and weather service officials.
"At this time we do not believe that there are any areas of our coast excluded from potential serious damage," the governor said in a statement.

At 5 a.m. EDT (0900 GMT), Fran was about 540 miles (869 km) from Charleston, South Carolina, and National Hurricane Center forecasters predicted the storm might make landfall on Thursday. Hurricane-strength winds extended 85 miles (136 km).
A hurricane watch area extended from Sebastian Inlet near Vero Beach, Florida, to Little River Inlet at the border of North and South Carolina.
"This storm also has the potential to take a Hugo-like track though the inland counties of South Carolina," Beasley said, recalling the 1989 hurricane that ravaged the Charleston area.
"Therefore, I urge residents of modular and mobile homes in particular to secure their homes and consider relocating to safer shelters," he added.
The previous hurricanes Bertha and Edouard that spared South Carolina this year were no grounds to become complacent, Beasely said, emphasizing the size of Fran.
"She is a relentless adversary and we must be prepared," he said in the statement.
